awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a GC triple quadrupole mass spectrometer for Environmental and Biogeochemical research
awd_abstract_narration:
Environmental assessment and ecosystem-level research requires advanced analytical capabilities. This acquisition of a gas chromatograph with a triple quadrupole mass spectrometer will provide a previously unavailable instrument to South Texas scientists studying biogeochemical cycling and environmental contaminants. This instrument has the ability to detect and quantify thousands of compounds, including anthropogenic contaminants, that can then be studied in greater detail to assess their metabolic role or influence on ecosystems. These areas of research are vital, not only to the rapidly developing and industrialized South Texas region but throughout the northern Gulf of Mexico. Additionally, with much of this region experiencing regular extreme weather events and environmental change, this instrument will play a role in understanding how our ecosystems are adapting to this shifting reality.

This instrument has capabilities that will enable a broad range of research for the faculty at Texas A&M University Corpus-Christi, but also other Hispanic Serving Institutions in our region. Some of the potential areas of research enabled by this instrument include: assessing the fate, transport and ecosystem effects of industrial and agricultural contaminants; determination of bacterial metabolites in freshwater and marine sediment; analysis of amino acids in sediment organic matter and biological matrixes; determination of natural organic matter biomarkers; analysis of atmospheric dissolved organic nitrogen. These studies will encompass basic and applied research that seeks to examine natural scientific processes and the ways in which humans are influencing our world.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This funding acquired a GC Triple Quadrupole Mass Spectrometer (GC-MS/MS) and a GC for a previously funded NSF MRI instrument (Thermo Orbitrap Fusion). The GC was installed in early 2019, while the GC-MS/MS was installed in late 2020 due to facility reorganization and pandemic-related delays. To date, six graduate students (5 master's and 1 Ph.D.) are trained on the instrument, each using it for aspects of their research. Three master's students are Hispanic, and the Ph.D. student is African American. This instrument was demonstrated in the PIs Environmental Chemistry course and lab in 2021, exposing 17 students to the capabilities of this analytical hardware. The instrument will be demonstrated for all future sections taught by the PI. It is also open for use by other courses at Texas A&M University-Corpus Christi. Furthermore, this instrument is accessible to researchers at Texas A&M University-Corpus Christi and other institutions in our region. We have had interest from a couple of labs regarding capabilities and expect some instrument use in the coming year from those groups. The GC-MS/MS and GC Orbitrap Fusion are currently used to study environmental contaminants and biogeochemical cycling in South Texas. Methods are developed to analyze polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, pesticides, and legacy pollution in coastal bays and groundwater. These studies are ongoing or just starting. However, one manuscript is currently in preparation. In closing, these instruments have vastly improved our campus' analytical capabilities and now serve as a catalyst for education and research into pollution and biogeochemical cycling in South Texas. 

 


Last Modified: 01/18/2022
Modified by: Jeremy Conkle
